title-group.article-title: Screening for Sleep Disorders in Pediatric Primary Care
title-group.subtitle: Are We There Yet?

article-meta.aff: 1Albert Einstein College of Medicine, St Barnabas Hospital, Astoria, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Daniel Erichsen, Department of Pediatrics, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, St Barnabas Hospital, 21-80 38th Street, Apt A2, Astoria, NY 11105, USA Email: danie.erichsen@gmail.com

abstract.p: Objectives. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and habitual snoring are highly prevalent childhood conditions and have been associated with a large array of negative health outcomes. Although guidelines were published by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) a decade ago recommending routine screening of sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) in primary care settings, it remains unclear to what extent such guidelines have been implemented and resulted in effective SDB screening. The aim of this study was to determine if AAP guidelines are adhered to in pediatric primary care. Study design. In all, 1032 electronic charts of children 4 to 17 years old presenting for well-child visits to 17 pediatricians between January 1 and December 31, 2010, were manually reviewed. Abstracted data included demographic variables and documentation of snoring as well as other sleep-related complaints. Results. The mean age was 8.5 ± 3.9 years (mean ± standard deviation), 49.9% were male, and 79.7% were Hispanic; 24.4% (n = 252) were screened for snoring. Of the children screened for sleep-related issues, 34.1% (n = 86) snored, but the majority of them (61.6%, n = 53) received no further evaluation. In the present sample, 0.5% (n = 5) had a diagnosis of OSA. Conclusions. The low prevalence of OSA may be explained by the relatively low frequency of sleep-related problem screening by pediatricians and thus the inordinately low adherence to the AAP guidelines. Modification and transition to electronic medical records as well as expanded efforts to educate health care providers and caregivers may improve detection and timely treatment of children at risk for SDB.

kwd-group.kwd: primary care and obstructive sleep apnea

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and habitual snoring (HS) are highly prevalent conditions in children: around 10% to 30% for HS and 1% to 4% for OSA have been reported in cross-sectional studies.1-8 Both HS and OSA are associated with a vast array of adverse health consequences, such as neurocognitive and behavioral impairments, decreased academic performance, and alterations in metabolic and cardiovascular function, which can ultimately promote deleterious outcomes even in adulthood.9-22 HS is defined per consensus as the presence of nocturnal snoring for 3 or more nights on average per week, and the diagnosis of OSA and its severity is based on the presence of specific respiratory and electroencephalographic alterations in the overnight polysomnogram.23-25 Furthermore, timely diagnosis and treatment of sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) is associated with marked improvements and reversibility of the disease-associated morbidities.26-29 To ensure that children with SDB receive appropriate attention from health care providers, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) issued a set of evidence-based recommendations in 2002, whereby screening for snoring should be a constitutive and essential component of all well-child visits. Specifically, whether a child snores or not should be documented, and if affirmative, appropriate additional steps such as further history taking to elicit other symptoms of SDB should be considered.30 To what extent these recommendations are adhered to by pediatricians has not previously been investigated. The aim of this study was to examine the extent of implementation of such AAP guidelines among a diverse group of independently practicing pediatricians affiliated with a midsized community hospital.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A consecutive sample of patients seen for any reason at 3 clinic locations between January 3 and February 28 was generated from the electronic medical records (EMRs). Charts of all patients that had well-child visits between January 1 and December 31, 2010, were selected for review. Abstracted data from each medical record included screening for snoring or other symptoms of SDB, such as choking episodes in sleep, and witnessed apneas as well as demographic information. This study was approved by the St Barnabas Hospital Institutional Review Board.

Data were analyzed using IBM Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS, version 20, Chicago, IL). Categorical variables were analyzed using Pearsons’s χ2 with appropriate corrections, and dimensional variables were analyzed using the independent sample t test. A P level of <.05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mean age was 8.5 ± 3.9 years (mean ± standard deviation), with girls being slightly, albeit significantly, older than boys (8.9 ± 4.1 vs 8.2 ± 3.6 years, P = .02). The majority of our cohort (79.7%, n = 823) were Hispanics, and 20.3% (n = 209) comprised all other ethnic groups. Table 1 illustrates the demographic characteristics of our study population.

caption.p: Demographic Characteristics of the Study Population

tr.td: Large tonsils were excluded in regression

sec.p: Only 24.4% (n = 252) of the children were asked if they snored. Of those, 34.1% (n = 86) answered affirmatively. Of the children who snored, 75% (n = 64) were also asked about witnessed apneas, which were affirmatively reported in 14% (n = 9). No documentation of choking episodes, snoring frequency, enuresis, diaphoresis, or any other signs of respiratory distress during sleep was found in any of the charts. Physicians’ actions for the 86 children with reported snoring are illustrated in Figure 1. Among these, the prevalence of diagnosed OSA was 0.5% (n = 5).

caption.p: Screening for and management of snoring.
Abbreviations: OSA, obstructive sleep apnea; ABP, American Academy of Pediatrics

sec.p: Of the 22 children with documented enlarged tonsils who were also screened for snoring, 81.8% (n = 18) did snore, and snoring was significantly more frequent than in children without enlarged tonsils (P < .001). Children with enlarged tonsils were younger than children without enlarged tonsils (5.8 ± 2.3 vs 8.6 ± 3.9 years, P < .001).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: HS and OSA are common conditions in children and are associated with negative health outcomes in several domains, including neurocognitive, cardiovascular, and metabolic complications. A decade ago, the AAP established guidelines that recommended every child to be screened for snoring when presenting for a health maintenance visit. The rationale behind this recommendation relied on the documented evidence that absence of snoring is uncommon in children with clinically significant SDB, making snoring a sensitive marker for screening in pediatric primary care. Over the past decade, the consequences of SDB have been firmly demonstrated; however, our preheld notion was that adherence to the AAP guidelines remained poor.

This study confirms the hypothesis that primary pediatric practices are highly unlikely to screen for OSA, despite the recommendations and guidelines set forth by the AAP. Indeed, only 1 of every 4 children who presented for routine health maintenance visits was assessed for snoring. When this question was asked, however, the yield was high because 1 in every 3 patients did report snoring. The prevalence of OSA was unexpectedly low compared with population studies, and this finding most likely reflects the low frequency of screening practices described in the present survey. This is all the more likely when considering the fact that snoring was present in a third of those asked, such that the OSA prevalence of 0.5% was likely markedly underestimated.

None of the pediatricians determined whether snoring, when reported, was habitual or occasional. There is a vast body of evidence to support that HS in itself has negative health outcomes in children, particularly related to neurocognitive ability and academic performance. However, there may be less of a concern if snoring is exclusively present in the setting of an upper-respiratory tract infection or during a flare up of nasal allergies. The striking absence of any evaluation of the frequency of snoring suggests that this may be a propitious target for education of primary care providers.

This study illustrates how, despite a growing awareness of the negative consequences of SDB in children and the availability of guidelines for the management of this spectrum of disease, screening remains an area with much room for improvement. In our study, we did not address the providers’ comfort levels with caring for children with SDB nor did we assess whether they were aware of the AAP guidelines for the management of this subset of children. However, a recent study demonstrated that pediatricians desire to be more actively involved in caring for patients with SDB. In this context, a sense of not feeling adequately trained to provide optimal care for this spectrum of disease emerges as a barrier.31 Other studies have demonstrated that the curriculum of most medical schools and residency training programs offer extremely limited exposure to SDB. The core problem may thus be insufficient emphasis on pediatric sleep disorders at various stages of medical training.32

Another barrier to implementation of appropriate screening practices may be the time constraints imposed on the practitioners in primary care.33 A clinical reality is that it is necessary for pediatricians to care for an increasing number of children, and such increased burden may detract from implementing routine screening for sleep disorders as well as screening for other conditions so as to provide excellent health maintenance. As part of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act passed in 2009, a federal mandate to convert all medical records to an electronic format will be enforced by 2014. In much of the industrial world, EMRs are already in routine use and may offer an opportune pathway toward effective screening for SDB. In the EMRs reviewed for this study, the template for well-child visits included a section for documentation of bed time and wake up time as well as for general sleep concerns. Although these are important pieces of information, perhaps replacing or adding a single question such as, “Does your child snore most nights?” could achieve the dual goals of increasing efficiency and adherence to current guidelines.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Screening for snoring in children remains a markedly underperforming area with great potential for future improvement. Current barriers to screening may include insufficient exposure to SDB at various levels of medical training, including residency training, as well as a high volume of patients seen in primary care. Further education of caregivers and caretakers as well as modifications of EMRs to reflect AAP guidelines may improve screening and ultimately care for children with SDB.

fn.label: Authors’ Note
fn.p: DE wrote this manuscript. DE and JA supervised CG and FG who collected the data. DR, CG, and FG performed the statistical analysis. JA and DG edited the manuscript.
